title-group.article-title: Expected Future Interest Rates and the Timing of Private Placements

abstract.p: In this study, I examine firms' timing behavior in the U.S. private placement market. Using a detailed sample of 2,164 private placements and 144a issues, I find that managers tend to base their decision on how much to borrow on the term spread (i.e. the difference between the long- and short-term yields). I also find that, ex-post, firms are successful: They tend to borrow more when the rates are low compared to the realized future rates. When I examine the relation between the term spread and the maturity choice, I find that when the term spread widens, firms tend to choose shorter maturities. This is in line with previous studies. Then, I test to see if firms that borrow more when the rates are low have significantly different leverage ratios compared to the other firms and find that timing does not seem to have a persistent impact on leverage. Finally, my subperiod tests reveal that during the 1998-2004 period, the term spread does not explain the amount borrowed or the maturity of the offering. Therefore, I conclude that further research is needed to identify firms' motives in this period, which includes the 2000-2001 recession.
